name: Capsule Hotel Asakusa Riverside

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed December 2012, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: You have to try the capsule hotel while in Tokyo, and this was a good option in that case. The mattress is not thicker than 5 cm, so the sleep was... not constant through the night. The "wi-fi-room" was packed with smoke at the time we wanted to sit there, so no use for that, and there were no electric outlets in the capsule. Also, it was poorly described in the capsule in english what the buttons were too, as well as how the TV could work. For the price, it's worth the stay one night, but I recommmend one night only.
reviews.title: Capsule hotel - just for the experience

reviews.text: I stayed at the capsule hotel for one night, August 27th. It was novel and served its purpose.
reviews.title: Capsule Hotel Asakusa Riverside

reviews.text: When we got there, it was 50 degrees Celsius (+110 farenheit) so it was damn hot. They did not air condition the hallways or elevators, so you sweated a lot. And when we first got there, they also weren't air conditioning the room with the capsules. Once we pointed out that there was no a/c however, they turned it on.
reviews.title: capsule hotel for the experience

reviews.text: Customer service was typical for Japan, meaning very good. Not too much English is spoken but you can get by with gestures, believe it or not. Everything was pretty clean, so no complaints there. The showering area was actually onsen-style and if you are not used to traditional Japanese baths, this will be odd. It's an open room with showers along one wall and a large hot-tub style bath, always filled with hot water. You need to rinse off at the showers first (and you do this seated, not standing), take a dip in the hot tub to warm up, go back to the showers where you wash yourself (hair and body), be sure to rinse off completely, and then you go back to the tub to hang for awhile. It's communal and everyone is naked. Women and men are separated however.
reviews.title: Smart, unique and cheap.. capsule hotel, the real japanese experience!!!! Smart

reviews.text: The capsule itself is surprisingly spacious. It has a tv, radio and alarm, but no where to plug in your phone or Ipod. There was a charger on the 2nd floor that you pay for though (where there was also free internet). They provided pj's and a towel, which was great. The mattress you sleep on is thin and too hard for my liking. Even with the a/c on I did not use my blanket, as I still found it a tad warm. I ended up using the blanket as a second pillow. Luggage storage is available on the second floor, which was 400 Yen for a locker. I ended up leaving my luggage in a nook by my capsule. Not sure if that was kosher or not but no one said anything.
reviews.title: Good for the experience but wouldn't stay more than 1 night!

reviews.text: i went there for one stay to try another capsule hotel in japan and i was very disappointed when it comes to the cleaninless issue.
reviews.title: Very dirty

reviews.text: though i had a good sleep, everything was dirty, from the lockers to the sticky light switches. i can understand that the building/facilities was old, but that's not an excuse in my book!
reviews.title: Good location, but bad capsule facilities

reviews.text: i had clean sheets in my capsule but i knew, seeing the rest of the hotel, that nobody ever had bothered to clean the walls of the capsules. and note that i'm an easy going traveler, still i was very annoyed. of course i didn't even thought of entering the onsen pool!!
reviews.title: Great Experience

reviews.text: Me and my boyfriend like to stay in capsule hotels in Japan, unfortunately for me many hotel are for man only. Capsule Riverside Hotel was a big disappointment, it's very old and many public places are very smoky, it's was a fist capsule where reception tried to sell shampoo (it's available inside for free be aware), bath area is not so good, area for make-up in lady's section didn't have any chairs to seat - i had to do make up standing. Lockers are very small, you have to use coin locker - 400 yen per 12 hours, but it's happen before with me (thou in some capsules reception could keep your luggage for free but it's not often). If you are traveling by male company try another capsules to get real experience with saunas and big , if you are traveling female- mix company and you are late to find somethings better - this place is ok for 1-2 night. One more time - it's not really capsules hat Japanese people used to, it's n more cheap hostel for tourist.
reviews.title: Loved the quiet comfort

reviews.text: Coming to Tokyo I knew I wanted to stay in the classic capsule hotels I had heard about and seen in movies, and Capsule Hotel Riverside doesn't disappoint. First, before going here you need to realize what you are going here for. It's for the experience, not lavish luxury (you're sleeping in a small box after all).
reviews.title: Unexpected International experience - loved it!

reviews.text: We reserved via Hostelworld, which required a 10% non refundable deposit. Stayed for just a night to try it out. I researched a lot prior to my visit. The only thing which worried me slightly was the comment that the capsule could be pretty warm since there was no air vent in the capsule. I even brought along a hand held battery operated fan!!!
reviews.title: Exceeded My (Low) Expectation!

reviews.text: Location
reviews.title: If i return to tokyo, i'll stay here

reviews.text: It was simple to find as long as you are aware that it is in the same building as the Hotel New Gyominso. Entrance is at the back while Gyominso’s at the main entrance. However, you can still enter via Gyominso's entrance. Look out for the round circular green roof.
reviews.title: For the sake of experience

reviews.text: The Toei Asakusa Line - about 2 min away (Exit A2b has elevator) but Exit 3 is the nearest. The Tobu Asakusa Line is 3 min away. However, there is a connecting passage from the Ginza Metro Station to the Toei Station.
reviews.title: Certainly worth the experience.

reviews.text: The Ginza Line Asakusa is 1 minute from the hotel. It is actually right outside (Exit 1 has elevator - access to the elevator is from 1 platform only.
reviews.title: quite good location

reviews.text: Same price as a dorm room in a youth hostel. No service at all, you even pay through a machine. The guy at the desk does not speak English. You pay for your luggage through lockers as expensive as the public ones, and for 12 hrs only. It looks old, like it has not been renovated for a while. We even saw a gigantic insect (un gros cafard). There is a female section. The shower is not on the same floor. Pros: it is a special experience, and they give you pyjamas, it is very close to the subway station but not that well posted.
reviews.title: Disappointed

reviews.text: convenient hostel, expensive lockers available (3000yen for a big bag for 12hours, you need to repay everytime you open), pot noodle vending machine, tv room.
reviews.title: Convenient Male/female capsule hotel

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed October 2010, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Nice view over the city on the roof.
reviews.title: Fun experience, but not sure of the value...and it smelled.

reviews.text: We did the capsule hotel just for one night for the experience of it, and it was pretty cool. The capsule was clean, had a light, tv, clock. The room with all of the capsules smelled bad. Bathroom was as clean as possible with that many people using it. Bath and shower area had a deck and fantastic views, super-cool. I was afraid I would not be able to sleep, but everyone was considerate and quiet and I actually slept really well. I am not sure how good of a value it was, but it was a cool experience.
reviews.title: Just try it

reviews.text: My sister and I absolutely loved this place, you gotta try a capsule while you're in Japan. This is one of the few capsule hotels that accept women. Cheap as, good location near the station in Asakusa where you probably will be visiting if you visit Tokyo. Sleeping was great, and I can't imagine it wouldn't be great unless you are claustrophobic or have noisy roommates. The capsules are surprisingly roomy, and have all the space you need. They provide lockers with your capsule so you have a place to store your things when you check-in. Staff were very friendly and used to foreigners. There is no room/capsule service so you'll only see them at the desk. Oh, be warned and the showers/baths are communal (segregated of course). But you've also gotta try that too while you're in Japan. So much space!
reviews.title: Good value for a novel experience

aka: Capsule Hotel Asakusa Riverside Tokyo, Japan
